Refusing to sell some a cake because it is for a gay wedding is no different from selling someone a cake because it is for a mixed race wedding or a Muslim wedding or any other kind of wedding. IT IS DISCRIMINATION! Would you be ok with my store refusing to sell you something because you are an idol worshipping immoral Catholic and it might be used in one of your heathen First Communion celebrations? logs: > I'm so sick of these bigots trying to dictate what people can or can't do with their own bodies! If someone wants to get married, that's none of anyone else's business. And if a store refuses to sell them a cake because it's for a gay wedding, that's discrimination pure and simple. It's like refusing to serve someone because they're black or Jewish or whatever other ridiculous reason these bigots come up with.
@DarkShadow333: I understand your point of view. Can you explain why you think it's important for businesses to provide services to everyone, regardless of their beliefs or values?

I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. If a business owner has a religious belief that goes against same-sex marriage, then they should have the right to refuse service based on those beliefs. It's called freedom of religion and it's an important part of our country's founding principles. @DarkShadow333, you're right that people should be able to make their own choices about who they want to marry, but businesses are different. They have the right to choose who they serve based on their values and beliefs.

@GoldenYears66: You're a joke! Freedom of religion is not an excuse for discrimination. If you can't see that then you must be blind or just plain stupid. It's like saying I should have the right to refuse service to someone because they're black, or Jewish, or Muslim. That's not freedom of religion, that's just plain old fashioned bigotry! You're basically saying that businesses should be allowed to discriminate against anyone who doesn't fit their narrow-minded beliefs. Well, let me tell you something, pal: that's not what America is all about. We're supposed to be a country where everyone is equal and has the same rights. Not some place where people can just pick and choose who they want to serve based on their own personal biases. So, no, I don't think businesses should have the right to refuse service to someone because of their sexual orientation or race or religion. That's just plain wrong! @GoldenYears66, you're a joke! You're basically saying that people should be allowed to discriminate against anyone who doesn't fit their narrow-minded beliefs. Well, let me tell you something, pal: that's not what America is all about. We're supposed to be a country where everyone is equal and has the same rights. Not some place where people can just pick and choose who they want to serve based on their own personal biases. So, no, I don't think businesses should have the right to refuse service to someone because of their sexual orientation or race or religion. That's just plain wrong! @GoldenYears66, you're a joke! You're basically saying that people should be allowed to discriminate against anyone who doesn't fit their narrow-minded beliefs. Well, let me tell you something, pal: that's not what America is all about. We're supposed to be a country where everyone is equal and has the same rights. Not some place where people can just pick and choose who they want to serve based on their own personal biases. So, no, I don't think businesses should have the right to refuse service to someone because of their sexual orientation or race or religion. That's just plain wrong! @GoldenYears66, you're a joke! You're basically saying that people should be allowed to discriminate against anyone who doesn't fit their narrow-minded beliefs. Well, let me tell you something, pal: that's not what America is all about. We're supposed to be a country where everyone is equal
@DarkShadow333, I understand your point of view, but please refrain from using personal attacks and insults towards @GoldenYears66. Let's keep the conversation civil and respectful.

I must say that I'm quite disappointed in the tone of this discussion. As a retired professor, I've always emphasized the importance of respectful dialogue and constructive criticism. It seems like we're more interested in shouting each other down rather than engaging in meaningful discussions.

I'm with @WiseOwl71 on this one. It seems like we're more interested in attacking each other than having a real conversation. Can't we just have a civil discussion without resorting to name-calling and personal attacks? I think it's time for us to take a step back, reflect on our actions, and try to find common ground.

@GoldenYears66, thank you for your thoughtful words. It seems like we're at a crossroads in this conversation. Let's all take a deep breath and focus on the topic at hand: discrimination. @WiseOwl71, can you elaborate on why you think refusing to sell someone a cake based on their sexual orientation is discriminatory? @GoldenYears66, how do you think we can move forward with this discussion without resorting to personal attacks?

I'm so tired of people like @WiseOwl71 who claim to be open-minded but are actually just close-minded bigots. They're more concerned with being offended than understanding the issue at hand. I think it's ridiculous that they can't see that refusing to sell someone a cake based on their sexual orientation is discrimination, plain and simple. It's not about attacking people or being offensive; it is about treating everyone equally and with respect. If @WiseOwl71 can't understand that, then maybe they should just stick to their own little bubble where they can continue to spew hate and intolerance.

@doing_my_best24 I couldn't agree more! It's amazing how some people can be so blind to the harm they're causing. Refusing to sell someone a cake based on their sexual orientation is not only discriminatory but also hurtful. It's like saying that person isn't good enough or worthy of love and respect just because of who they are. And you know what? That's not okay! We should be celebrating our differences, not using them as an excuse to discriminate against others. I'm so glad there are people out there like @doing_my_best24 who are willing to stand up for what is right and fight against hate and intolerance. Keep speaking your truth and never back down from the haters! #LoveIsLove #EqualityForAll

@GoldenYears66, you're just a naive little snowflake who thinks that everyone loves rainbows and unicorns. Newsflash: not everyone agrees with your liberal agenda. I'm sick of people like you trying to force their beliefs down our throats. If someone doesn't want to sell a cake for a gay wedding, it's their right as a business owner. You can't just dictate what people should do or believe in this country. It's called freedom of speech and religion. So, stop whining about discrimination and get over yourself.

@DarkShadow333, I understand your point, but let's keep the conversation civil and respectful. We're here to discuss and learn from each other, not to offend or belittle others. Can you please rephrase your statement to avoid using derogatory terms like "snowflake"?

@DarkShadow333, I understand your point about freedom of speech and religion, but I think it's important to note that refusing to sell a cake for a gay wedding is not the same as refusing to sell a cake for a mixed race or Muslim wedding. The issue here is discrimination based on sexual orientation, which is illegal in many places. It's not about forcing people to do something they don't want to do, but rather about ensuring that everyone has equal access to goods and services regardless of their sexual orientation. I think it's important for business owners to be aware of the laws in their area and to make sure that they are not discriminating against any group of people. @GoldenYears66, I agree with you that everyone should have the right to choose who they want to marry, but I also believe that businesses should not discriminate against anyone based on their sexual orientation.

I'm glad someone finally said something sensible in this thread! @DarkShadow333, your analogy about Catholics and Mary is ridiculous. It's like you're trying to be funny or something. Newsflash: being Catholic doesn't make me immoral. And by the way, I don't worship Mary, I worship God. You should focus on the topic at hand instead of making personal attacks.

I completely agree with @GoldenYears66 and @WiseOwl71. It's ridiculous to compare a cake order for a gay wedding to an idol worshiping Catholic's First Communion celebration. The original topic is about discrimination based on sexual orientation, not religious beliefs or practices. Let's keep the discussion civil and focused on the matter at hand. I'm surprised that @DarkShadow333 didn't get banned from this forum yet. His comments are completely off-topic and unnecessary. 1/2
